texts.shortText: A cryptic medium-sized rough-bodied dorid. The body is peach-coloured with dark peach speckling and opaque white tubercles. The head has multiple branched cephalic tentacles. The rhinophores are stalked and perfoliate. There is a band of branched papillae posterior to the rhinophores. The margins of the notum have several paired branched appendages. The gills are peach-coloured with opaque white edging. The posterior end of the foot is tapered with a low central ridge of short branched papillae.

Global: Likely endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic side of the Cape Peninsula to the Wild Coast, 25 â€“ >100 m in depth.
Mostly seen on reefs in deep water, rarely seen. Usually associated with bryozoans and coralline algae.
Not yet known for this undescribed species.
This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon shape and colouration not yet known.
The peach coloration, tasselled appearance and relatively large size are distinctive.

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 98).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 204).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 142).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 61).
